newsitem.title: CHINA: HK's Tung defends plan to deport children.
newsitem.headline: HK's Tung defends plan to deport children.

text.p: New Hong Kong leader Tung Chee-hwa on Wednesday defended his plan to introduce a bill that would deport illegal child migrants back to China.
Tung, speaking to reporters during a tour of China's garrison in the special Chinese region, denied that his draft legislation clashed with the Basic Law, the ex-British colony's constitution.
"Our decision is definitely not against the Basic Law," Tung said. The Basic Law took effect on July 1 after Britain handed the territory back to China, ending 156 years of colonial rule.
The Hong Kong government unveiled the immigration bill on Tuesday and asked the Provisional Legislature to rush it through during Wednesday's session, its first full sitting since the handover.

The new bill would allow the government to send home hundreds of youngsters -- most of whom claim residency rights through parents in Hong Kong but were smuggled in illegally from mainland China without waiting for legal clearance.
Legal experts and social activists in Hong Kong have criticised Tung's move, saying it contravenes the Basic Law by encroaching on the children's right of abode.
